conclusion: Solve step-by-step to find when gas starts to leak between chambers in the insulated cylinder
Cylinder of height 2H and volume 2V divided into two chambers by diaphragm of mass m
Initially, both chambers have equal volume V, pressure p, and temperature T
Diaphragm rests on a ledge with a gasket providing a tight seal
Piston at the bottom moves upward slowly
Gas will leak when pressure difference becomes large enough
Need to find volume V_0 of lower chamber when leakage begins
Given x = mgH/pV
For gas to start leaking, pressure difference must overcome force keeping diaphragm sealed
Force comes from weight of diaphragm (mg) and pressure forces from both sides
When piston moves up, volume of lower chamber decreases and upper chamber conditions remain constant
Lower chamber undergoes adiabatic compression: pV^γ = p_2V_0^γ
Leakage begins when upward force exceeds downward force on diaphragm
Upward force: p_2 * A, Downward force: p_1 * A + mg
At leakage: p_2 * A = p_1 * A + mg, thus p_2 = p_1 + mg/A
Area of cylinder: A = V/H, thus p_2 = p + mgH/V
Using x = mgH/pV, p_2 = p(1+x)
For adiabatic process: pV^(5/3) = p_2V_0^(5/3)
Substitute p_2 = p(1+x) into adiabatic relation
Simplify to V^(5/3) = (1+x)V_0^(5/3)
Rearrange to find V_0: V_0^(5/3) = V^(5/3)/(1+x)
